how_it_works.title: How Does It Work?
how_it_works.summary_text: You participate in democracy. You get paid. Not metaphorically—actually paid, in a currency backed by real improvements in your community's wellbeing.
how_it_works.intro: The Polis Protocol creates a new kind of economy where two things that were never valued before—democratic participation and care work—become the source of real wealth.

steps.title: Step 1: You Participate
steps.text: Your village faces a decision: Should we build a seawall or restore natural dunes for coastal protection? You don't just vote. You research. You deliberate with neighbors. You consider evidence. An AI assistant helps you understand complex tradeoffs—privately, without tracking your identity.

steps.title: Step 2: Quality Gets Measured
steps.text: The system doesn't just count votes. It measures the quality of participation. Did you engage with opposing arguments? Did you consider long-term effects? Did your contributions help the community reach better decisions? This isn't surveillance—it's recognition.

steps.title: Step 3: You Earn
steps.text: Quality participation earns you DemCoin. Care work—helping an elderly neighbor, volunteering at a community garden, raising children—earns you CareCoin reputation that multiplies your economic power. Both are tied to actual, measured improvements in community wellbeing.

steps.title: Step 4: Value is Created
steps.text: When your community's health improves, when trust increases, when the environment is protected—the currency supply expands. When things get worse, it contracts. The money itself tracks whether life is actually getting better.

sections.title: The Story They Tell
sections.text:
The Western narrative goes like this: Athens invented democracy 2,500 years ago. It worked briefly, then collapsed. Dark Ages followed. Eventually, the Enlightenment "rediscovered" democratic ideals and invented representative democracy—elect someone to decide for you. Progress.

This story is wrong.

sections.title: The Story We Lived
sections.text:
Democracy never died in Greece. It evolved.

When Christianity spread through the Greek world, it didn't replace democratic practice—it absorbed it. The word "Ekklisia" (Εκκλησία) means both "Church" and "Assembly." This is no coincidence. The same gathering that once debated policy in the Agora became the center of both spiritual and civic life. Unity of purpose. Community self-governance continued.

The Eastern Roman Empire—what the West dismissively calls "Byzantium"—was built on self-governed villages and cities. The Emperor's reach stopped at the boundaries of the Ekklisia. Local communities managed their own affairs, made their own decisions, maintained their own justice.

Even under Ottoman rule, this model persisted. The conquerors didn't impose a new system—they adopted ours. Self-governed communities continued for four centuries. The Ottomans involved themselves only in taxation and army recruitment. Everything else remained in the hands of the people.

For 2,500 years, Greeks lived democracy. Not perfectly. Not without interruption. But continuously.

sections.title: The Trade We Made
sections.text:
Then came the modern Greek state. And with it, a choice.

The Western powers who supported Greek independence brought their own model: representative democracy. Elect someone to decide for you. Centralized power. Professional politicians.

We traded 2,500 years of self-governance for an imported system barely fifty years old.

Had Kapodistrias lived longer, perhaps Greece would have developed something like Switzerland—direct democracy, local autonomy, federal structure. Instead, we got parliaments, parties, and the slow erosion of civic participation.

sections.title: The Crisis of the Imported Model
sections.text:
Today, representative democracy is failing everywhere:

- **Trust has collapsed.** Who believes politicians represent them? Who feels their voice matters?
- **AI is replacing jobs.** What happens when human labor is no longer economically necessary?
- **Care work remains invisible.** Parents, caregivers, volunteers—none of this counts in GDP.

The West is discovering what Greeks knew all along: you cannot delegate democracy. You must live it.

sections.title: The Opportunity We See
sections.text:
The same technologies threatening us could restore what we lost.

AI doesn't have to replace humans. It could amplify human wisdom—helping citizens understand complex policy without requiring expertise.

Blockchain doesn't have to be speculation. It could create transparent systems where value flows to those who create it.

Cryptography doesn't have to enable surveillance. It could guarantee privacy while enabling accountability.

sections.title: What We're Building
sections.text: The Polis Protocol is not an invention. It is a restoration—upgraded for the digital age.

aegis.title: AEGIS: The Privacy Shield
aegis.intro:
The paradox: To help you effectively, AI needs to know everything about you. But if AI knows everything about you, you're under surveillance.

Our solution: AI knows everything about you—but that AI lives only on your device.

items.label: Layer 1: Your Local AI Agent
items.text:
A small but capable AI runs directly on your phone or computer. It has complete access to your participation history, your care work records, your deliberation contributions. It knows you as well as a trusted advisor would.

This data never leaves your device. Not to our servers. Not to any cloud. Nowhere.

items.label: Layer 2: Anonymous Cloud Assistance
items.text:
Sometimes you need analysis that's too complex for on-device processing. When that happens, your local AI strips all identifying information from your query. It removes your name, location, writing style—anything that could fingerprint you.

The anonymized query travels through privacy-preserving networks (like Tor) to reach sophisticated cloud AI. The cloud AI sees: "A citizen is evaluating coastal protection options." It does not see: "Petros Bakolas from Preveza is researching seawalls."

items.label: Layer 3: Cryptographic Guarantees
items.text:
Zero-knowledge proofs let you prove things without revealing them. You can prove you're eligible to vote without revealing your identity. You can prove you have care work experience without revealing whose care you provided.

This isn't policy ("we promise not to look"). This is mathematics ("we literally cannot look").

aegis.why_matters_text:
In current systems, every time you ask AI for help, you create a record that can be:
- Sold to advertisers
- Subpoenaed by governments
- Leaked in data breaches
- Used to manipulate you

In Aegis, you get better AI assistance (because your local agent knows your full context) with zero surveillance risk (because identifying data never leaves your control).
aegis.footer_text: Your data. Your device. Your democracy.

dual_token.title: The Dual Token System: DemCoin & CareCoin
dual_token.intro:
One mission. Two currencies. Complete alignment.

The Polis Protocol uses two complementary tokens, each recognizing a different kind of value that current economies ignore.

demcoin.title: DemCoin: Get Paid to Participate
demcoin.what_is: What it is: A currency you earn through quality democratic participation.
how_earn_list: Contributing to decisions that improve community outcomes
demcoin.quality_text: AI systems (running locally, preserving your privacy) assess the depth and quality of your engagement. Did you just rubber-stamp? Or did you actually wrestle with the complexity?
demcoin.why_works:
DemCoin is tied to the Social Value Index (SVI). When community wellbeing improves, new currency is minted and distributed to those who contributed to good decisions. When things get worse, the supply contracts.

This means wise governance is profitable. For the first time, making good decisions for your community directly increases your economic wealth.

carecoin.title: CareCoin: Recognition for Care
carecoin.what_is: What it is: A non-transferable reputation that multiplies your economic power.
how_earn_list: Caring for children, elderly, or disabled family members
Any work that creates value but isn't paid by the market
carecoin.different_text: CareCoin is not a currency you spend. It's living reputation:

different_items.label: Non-transferable
different_items.text: You can't sell it or give it away

different_items.label: Decaying
different_items.text: It diminishes over time (about 20% yearly), requiring ongoing contribution

different_items.label: Multiplying
different_items.text: It increases your purchasing power when spending DemCoin

carecoin.why_matters: A grandmother caring for her disabled grandson finally receives economic recognition. Not charity—recognition of value she actually creates. Her care work measurably improves health outcomes, family stability, and community wellbeing. The system sees this and rewards it.

dual_token.together_intro: You need both tokens to thrive in the Polis economy:

together_items.label: DemCoin without CareCoin
together_items.text: You can participate in governance, but your economic power is limited

together_items.label: CareCoin without DemCoin
together_items.text: You're recognized for care, but have no voice in how the system evolves

dual_token.together_footer:
This creates a virtuous cycle: Governance teaches you to think systematically. Care work grounds you in real human needs. You become a better citizen by doing both.

Wisdom and care, finally valued.

svi.title: SVI: The Social Value Index
svi.intro:
What if we measured what actually matters?

GDP measures transactions. A car crash increases GDP (hospital bills, repairs, legal fees). Cancer treatment increases GDP. Divorce increases GDP. War increases GDP spectacularly.

Meanwhile, GDP is blind to what makes life worth living. A grandmother caring for her grandchild? Zero GDP. A community garden feeding families? Minimal GDP. Friends gathering to make music? Zero GDP.

We're optimizing for the wrong metric.
svi.dimensions_intro: SVI measures wellbeing across four interconnected dimensions:

dimensions.title: Economic
items: Median household income (not averages skewed by billionaires)
Wealth distribution (is prosperity shared or hoarded?)
Local production capacity (can we make what we need?)

dimensions.title: Social
items: Mental health and absence of loneliness

svi.changes_intro: In the Polis economy, currency is minted when SVI improves. This isn't metaphor—it's code.

scenarios.title: Scenario A: Extractive Development
scenarios.text:
A factory promises 5% GDP growth but brings pollution, low wages, and wealth extraction to distant shareholders. Under GDP metrics, this is "success."

Under SVI: Economic dimension shows modest gains. Social dimension shows decline (health impacts, weakened community). Ecological dimension shows significant decline. Overall SVI falls. Currency contracts. Those who supported this policy lose wealth.

scenarios.title: Scenario B: Regenerative Development
scenarios.text:
A cooperative network uses clean technology, pays living wages, reinvests locally. GDP growth is only 2%—"failure" by traditional metrics.

Under SVI: All four dimensions show improvement. Overall SVI rises. Currency expands. Those who supported this policy gain wealth.

svi.insight_text:
SVI makes sustainability profitable. Not through regulation, not through moral appeals, but through direct economic incentive.

When your money itself tracks whether life is getting better, extractive behavior becomes economically irrational. Cooperation becomes the optimal strategy. Long-term thinking pays off immediately.
svi.footer: We stop measuring activity and start measuring flourishing.
